item.title: Arkansas Tries To Stop An Epidemic Of Herbicide Damage
item.description: June 23, 2017 - A weedkiller called dicamba, which farmers hoped could banish herbicide-resistant weeds, has become a plague itself in Arkansas. The state's regulators just voted to ban it for 120 days.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 23, 2017 - A weedkiller called dicamba, which farmers hoped could banish herbicide-resistant weeds, has become a plague itself in Arkansas. The state's regulators just voted to ban it for 120 days. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/06/23/534117683/arkansas-tries-to-stop-an-epidemic-of-herbicide-damage

item.title: What Uber's Leadership Change Means For Diversity In Tech
item.description: June 23, 2017 - NPR's Rachel Martin speaks to tech industry recruiter and consultant Y-Vonne Hutchinson about the resignation of former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick, and the message it sends to Silicon Valley.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 23, 2017 - NPR's Rachel Martin speaks to tech industry recruiter and consultant Y-Vonne Hutchinson about the resignation of former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick, and the message it sends to Silicon Valley. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/23/534056720/what-ubers-leadership-change-means-for-diversity-in-tech

item.title: Facebook Changes Its Mission With Announcement About Groups
item.description: June 22, 2017 - Facebook has nearly 2 billion users. But that's not enough. Now, in an effort to go deep, not just wide, the company will focus on users' activity levels.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 22, 2017 - Facebook has nearly 2 billion users. But that's not enough. Now, in an effort to go deep, not just wide, the company will focus on users' activity levels. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/06/22/534018001/facebook-changes-its-mission-with-groups-announcement

item.title: Man Accused Of Making Millions Of Robocalls Faces Biggest-Ever FCC Fine
item.description: June 22, 2017 - FCC proposed a $120 million fine for a Miami resident said to be single-handedly responsible for 97 million robocalls over a three-month period, scheming to sell "discounted" travel packages.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 22, 2017 - FCC proposed a $120 million fine for a Miami resident said to be single-handedly responsible for 97 million robocalls over a three-month period, scheming to sell "discounted" travel packages. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/22/533970545/man-accused-of-making-millions-of-robocalls-faces-biggest-ever-fcc-fine

item.title: FCC Takes Up Emergency 'Blue Alerts' For Threats To Law Enforcement
item.description: June 22, 2017 - Created in 2015, Blue Alerts are similar to Amber Alerts, but aim to catch people who threaten or harm police officers. The DOJ asked the FCC to add a special code to the broadcast emergency system.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 22, 2017 - Created in 2015, Blue Alerts are similar to Amber Alerts, but aim to catch people who threaten or harm police officers. The DOJ asked the FCC to add a special code to the broadcast emergency system. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/22/533660081/fcc-moves-to-streamline-emergency-blue-alerts-for-threats-to-law-enforcement

item.title: Moth Eyes Inspire Glare-Resistant Coating For Cellphone Screens
item.description: June 22, 2017 - The scientists who developed the anti-reflective film were inspired by tiny, light-trapping structures on moth eyes that help the insects avoid predators.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 22, 2017 - The scientists who developed the anti-reflective film were inspired by tiny, light-trapping structures on moth eyes that help the insects avoid predators. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/22/533803686/moth-eyes-inspire-glare-resistant-coating-for-cellphone-screens

item.title: Is Big Tech Getting Too Big?
item.description:
June 22, 2017 - Silicon Valley leaders like Uber's former CEO Travis Kalanick have unprecedented power. At what point should the rest of us push back?
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-06-22/is-big-tech-getting-too-big

item.title: How Facebook Uses Technology To Block Terrorist-Related Content
item.description: June 22, 2017 - Social media firms are under pressure to block extremist activity on their sites. Facebook is hiring thousands more people to review content, but artificial intelligence also plays a role.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 22, 2017 - Social media firms are under pressure to block extremist activity on their sites. Facebook is hiring thousands more people to review content, but artificial intelligence also plays a role. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/06/22/533855547/how-facebook-uses-technology-to-block-terrorist-related-content

item.title: After CEO Resignation, Is Uber Kalanick-less Or Kalanick-free?
item.description: June 21, 2017 - Few companies have had such a rapid fallout from such a vast number of crises stemming from the workplace culture perpetuated from the top, while appearing to be at the peak of its success.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 21, 2017 - Few companies have had such a rapid fallout from such a vast number of crises stemming from the workplace culture perpetuated from the top, while appearing to be at the peak of its success. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/06/21/533791446/after-ceo-resignation-is-uber-kalanick-less-or-kalanick-free

item.title: Intel Signs On As An Olympic Sponsor, Promising Virtual Reality And 360-Degree Video
item.description: June 21, 2017 - Intel's CEO says it "will accelerate the adoption of technology for the future of sports on the world's largest athletic stage."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Jump Rope Heroes: Watch School Kids Set A One-Minute Guinness World Record
item.description: June 21, 2017 - In a blur of coordination, a team of 14 students blew away the old record for most skips through a single jump rope in one minute.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: What's Washington Got To Hide?
item.description:
June 21, 2017 - It seems like more and more of the U.S. government's business is taking place behind closed doors. What aren't we being told, and why?
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-06-21/whats-washington-got-to-hide

item.title: U.S. Elections Systems Vulnerable, Lawmakers Told In Dueling Hearings
item.description: June 21, 2017 - Jeh Johnson, Homeland Security secretary during the 2016 election, testified before the House Intelligence Committee while the Senate Intelligence Committee heard from cybersecurity experts.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick Resigns
item.description: June 21, 2017 - Uber CEO Travis Kalanick has resigned from his post after pressure from shareholders. His leadership at the company proved controversial. David Greene talks with Mike Isaac of The New York Times.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 21, 2017 - Uber CEO Travis Kalanick has resigned from his post after pressure from shareholders. His leadership at the company proved controversial. David Greene talks with Mike Isaac of The New York Times. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/21/533764339/uber-ceo-travis-kalanick-resigns
